metadata.title: UNIT GROUPS OF SOME MULTIQUADRATIC NUMBER FIELDS AND 2-CLASS GROUPS

abstract.text: Let p ≡ −q ≡ 5 (mod 8) be two prime integers. In this paper, we investigate the unit groups of the fields
. Furthermore , we give the second 2-class groups of the subextensions of L 1 as well the 2-class groups of the fields L n = Q( √ p, √ q, ζ 2 n+2 ) and their maximal real subfelds.

body_text.text: This paper was written to commemorate the innocent victims of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic all around the world. Let k be a number field and E k its unit group. The determination of E k is a very difficult computational problem that serves to give answers on many problems such as the computation of the class number of k, the capitulation problem and many other problems in algebraic number theory. The most spectacular result that describes the structure of E k is the well known Dirichlet's unit theorem that says that
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: where µ(k) is the group of roots of unity contained in k, r 1 is the number of real embeddings and r 2 the number of conjugate pairs of complex embeddings of k. This is the only known and general result that covers any given number field k. If k is an imaginary J-field there is a known result of Hasse that gives the difference between the unit group of k and that of its real maximal subfield k + i.e., the index [E k : µ(k)E k + ] equals 1 or 2.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Unfortunately, these results do not give much information on the generators of the group E k . For the particular family of multiquadratic number fields there are some useful algorithms by Wada (cf. [16] ) and Azizi (cf. [3] ) that helped to compute the unit groups of many families of real biquadratic number fields and imaginary triquadratic number fields (cf. [7, 4] ). Whereas these algorithms became very difficult to be applied for real multiquadratic fields of degree ≥ 8 and imaginary multiquadratic fields of degree ≥ 16. In the best of our knowledge there is only one example, in literature, that explicitly determines the unit groups of some infinite families of such fields (see the recently submitted paper [9] ). In §2 of this paper we shall reinforce the algorithms of Wada and Azizi by a process of elimination based on norm maps and class number formulas to explicitly determine unit groups of the fields
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: , where p and q are two primes that verify one of the following conditions:
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In §3, we determine the 2-class groups and the second 2-class groups of the unramified quadratic extensions of Q( √ 2pq, i), as well we give the 2-class groups of the layers of their cyclotomic Z 2 -extension.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Let k be a number field. We shall respect the following notations for the rest of this paper:
body_text.section: Notations

body_text.text: The fundamental unit of the quadratic field Q( √ d), * E k : The unit group of k, * FSU: Abbreviation of "fundamental system of units", * k (1) : The Hilbert 2-class field of k, * k (2) : The Hilbert 2-class field of k (1) , * k + : The maximal real subfield of k, whenever k is imaginary,
body_text.section: Notations

body_text.text: The unit index of k, if k is multiquadratic and k i are the quadratic subfields of k, * N k ′ /k : The norm map of an extension k ′ /k.
body_text.section: Notations

body_text.text: Units of some mutiquadratic number fields of degree 8 and 16

Let K 0 be a real number field, K = K 0 (i) a quadratic extension of K 0 , n ≥ 2 be an integer and ξ n a 2 n -th primitive root of unity, then ξ n = 1 2 (µ n + λ n i), where µ n = √ 2 + µ n , λ n = √ 2 − µ n−1 , µ 2 = 0, λ 0 = 2 and µ 3 = λ 3 = √ 2. Let n 0 be the greatest integer such that ξ n 0 is contained in K, {ε 1 , ..., ε r } a fundamental system of units of K 0 and ε a unit of K 0 such that (2 + µ n 0 )ε is a square in K 0 (if it exists). Then a fundamental system of units of K is one of the following systems :

UNITS AND 2-CLASS FIELD TOWERS... 13 3. Remarks on the Hilbert 2-class field towers and the cyclotomic Z 2 -extensionsLet k be an algebraic number field and Cl 2 (k) the 2-Sylow subgroup of its ideal class group Cl(k). Let k (1) (resp. k (2) ) be the first (resp. second) Hilbert 2-class field of k and put G = Gal(k (2) /k), then if G ′ denotes the commutator subgroup of G, we have by class field theory G ′ ≃ Gal(k (2) /k (1) ) and G/G ′ ≃ Gal(k (1) /k) ≃ Cl 2 (k). Assume in all what follows that Cl 2 (k) is of type (2, 2), then in [14] , Kisilevsky showed that G is isomorphic to Z/2Z × Z/2Z, Q m , D m or S m , where Q m , D m , and S m denote the quaternion, dihedral and semidihedral groups respectively, of order 2 m , where m ≥ 3 and m ≥ 4 for S m . Let F 1 , F 2 and F 3 be the three quadratic unramified of k such that F 1 is cyclic. Then using some known results of group theory one can easily deduce from [14, Theorem 2] that we have (cf. [9, Remark 2.2]) :Remark 3.1. The 2-class groups of the two fields F 2 and F 3 are cyclic if and only if k (1) = k (2) or k (1) = k (2) and G ≃ Q 3 . In the other cases the 2-class groups F 2 and F 3 are of type (2, 2) (whereas that of F 1 is cyclic).Set the following notations:( Proof. Let k = Q( √ 2pq, i). By Remark 3.2, the 2-class group of k is of type (2, 2) . Note that L pq , F pq and K pq are the three unramified quadratic extension of k. Since by [8] the 2-class group L pq is cyclic, then the above preliminaries completes the proof.Since the 2-class group of L pq is cyclic, then the Hilbert 2-class field of L pq terminates at the first layer. Now we shall determine the structure of the groups Gal(F (2) pq /F pq ) and Gal(K If p and q verify conditions (2) , then we haveSince the 2-class group of L pq is cyclic (so its Hilbert 2-class field tower terminates at the first layer) and L 1,pq is an unramified extension of L pq , then the 2-class group of L 1,pq is also cyclic. As L 1,pq is also a quadratic unramified extension of both F pq and K pq , then by [9, Proposition 2.2] and Theorems 2.5 and 2.8 we have |Gal(F Remark 3.5. Put k = Q( √ 2pq, i) and assume that p and q are two primes verifying conditions (1) . The author of [2] did not determine the order of Gal(k (2) /k). Now it is easy to deduce that it is of order |Gal(k (2) /k)| = 2 m+1 (i.e, Gal(k (2) /k) ≃ Q m+1 ), where m is such that h 2 (−pq) = 2 m . Theorem 3.6. Let p and q be two primes satisfying conditions (1) or (2). Put π 1 = 2, π 2 = 2 + √ 2,..., π n = 2 + √ π n−1 , L n = Q( √ q, √ p, ζ 2 n+2 ) and L + n = Q( √ p, √ q, √ π n ). Then 1. For all n ≥ 1, the 2-class group of L + n is trivial. By Theorems 2.5 and 2.8, the class number of Q( √ p, √ q, √ 2) the first step of the cyclotomic Z 2 -extension of k is odd. So we have the first item by [11, Theorem 1] .

ref_spans.text: If p and q verify conditions (2)
